Reaction Factories (reaction_factories.py)¶

This module has code related to the creation of protein-ligand reactions. Description of the eventual models may be created from text files or via another method (e.g. GUI) and the reaction factory classes provide a means to interpret those sources and create reaction objects.

class reaction_factories.FileReactionFactory(filepath)¶

A class for reading reactions from a specially formatted file

get_initial_conditions()¶

Get the initial conditions from the file

Returns:a one-to-one dictionary of species symbols mapped to floats
get_reactions()¶

Get the reactions from this factory

Returns:a list of Reaction instances
get_simulation_time()¶

Gets the simulation time specified in the file. If this was not given in the file, it will end up returning None

Returns:float or None
class reaction_factories.GUIReactionFactory(reaction_strings_dict)¶

A class for obtaining a model specification via a GUI

get_initial_conditions()¶

Get the initial conditions. Due to the GUI setup,we do not necessarily have this information. It can be specified via the GUI at a later step in the workflow

Returns:None
get_reactions()¶

Gets a list of the Reaction objects

Returns:a list of Reaction instances
get_simulation_time()¶

Get the simulation time. Due to the GUI setup,we do not necessarily have this information. It can be specified via the GUI at a later step in the workflow

Returns:None
class reaction_factories.ReactionFactory¶

A base class to derive from. Derived children of ReactionFactory should provide a mechanism to ingest information and create Reaction instances to populate a Model.

Model solvers (model_solvers.py)¶

This module has code for solving the models. Generally, these will be iterative models solved by integration or root-finding methods.

class model_solvers.ODESolver(model)¶

This solver was the first implementation and did not explicitly calculate a Jacobian

Assumes that the rate constants and initial conditions are fixed, so this class is not suitable for use in performing curve-fitting operations (e.g. fitting rate constants).

equilibrium_solution()¶

Runs the integration to determine the equilibrium state

Returns:a 3-tuple consisting of the species-to-index map, a numPy array giving the evolution of each species in the columns, and an array of the time steps.
class model_solvers.ODESolverWJacobian(model)¶

This solver includes a Jacobian and allows changing initial conditions and rate constants. This allows for use in curve-fitting procedures.

equilibrium_solution(X0=None, k=None)¶

Runs the integration to determine the equilibrium state.

Note that it’s important that the array of rate constants is ordered in our convention. Printing the model object is one way to check the order of the reactions so that the rate constants can be arranged in the proper order.

Parameters:
  • X0 – (optional) A dictionary mapping the symbols to the initial concentrations
  • k – (optional) An array of rate constants.
Returns:

a 3-tuple consisting of the species-to-index map, a numPy array giving the evolution of each species in the columns, and an array of the time steps.
class model_solvers.Solver¶

A base class for general solvers we might create to solve for the equilibrium state.

Contains methods that are likely to be useful to derived classes.

Instantiate a derived class, not this one.
